How one thing a day will improve your life
06 Nov 2019 by LIFE HACKER AND PUBLISHING HOUSE ‚ÄúAST‚Äù
An excerpt from a psychotherapist‚Äôs book on how to subjugate an unconscious desire to procrastinate and absorb cakes for the night.
A client from one distant country once asked me: ‚ÄúDoctor, I am a specific person and I don‚Äôt like what I can‚Äôt touch, touch, see or hear. You tell me that my psyche, my head, my unconscious not only have their own, different from mine, outlook on my life, but they can also arbitrarily and imperceptibly control my behavior, change it and thereby affect my life. To be honest, I do not notice this and therefore I have to trust you, which I would not like. ‚ÄúCould you give specific examples of how this management is going on, so that I can see for myself and know what it is?‚Äù
I did not begin to tell her about Freud and give as an example a dream (‚Äúthe royal road to the unconscious‚Äù) for one reason. Dreams are not behavior. I can endlessly prove to you that dreams make sense and we are not the creators of dreams, and we do not put that meaning into them. We do not go to bed with the thought that this and that and that should be dreamed today, and "when he starts hugging and kissing me on the sofa, the door will open, mom will come in and ask if I forgot to stroke the clothes." You, for your part, will endlessly prove to me that dreams are just a set of incoherent and meaningless fragments of experienced events and memories in which the past day is distorted and chaotically reflected.
And I will have nothing to object to you. I am not an orthodox psychoanalyst, therefore I am not afraid to offend my colleagues. I have no doubt that dreams make sense, that this meaning can be understood, and that understanding this meaning can help a person change his life for the better. I only doubt that the modern interpretation of dreams is based on a solid objective scientific basis.
I will give you just one argument. It will be possible to speak of any objective approach to the analysis of dreams when we see that ten psychoanalysts, having independently analyzed each other‚Äôs dream, will make completely identical conclusions, and from these conclusions identical recommendations will be drawn and these recommendations will lead to identical results. . I have not heard of such a miracle.
Ten botanists from different countries, having seen a drying plant, should theoretically conclude that the plant does not have enough water and that it needs to be watered. Then they should water it, and objectively, after some time, the plant should feel better.
Ten doctors, having seen a set of certain symptoms, should, on the basis of this, make a certain diagnosis and offer specific treatment methods, the variations of which will again depend on specific details. But this is not so in psychoanalysis.
I can‚Äôt say that I have completely studied all the existing professional literature, but I have never seen publications in which the results of a comparative study of the opinions of several dozen psychoanalysts regarding the same specific dream were presented. I believe that if such data were available, they would be included in all the basic guidelines for psychoanalysis. But no.
Therefore, it seems to me that readers of dream books can more justifiably claim a scientific approach. They at least have no disagreement in their interpretation: if a tooth is lost, it means the death of a loved one, and if excrement - money. ‚ÄúUnscience‚Äù in dream books begins when the question is asked: ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù. But we are too far removed from our topic. We return to the client.
I offered her another way. It is absolutely concrete, practical, tangible and famous. I wrote about him repeatedly. And not just me. The only thing I have always emphasized is that the main value of this method is not what they attribute to it: not the systematization and organization of one‚Äôs life. Its main significance is that it allows the person himself to determine exactly how ‚Äúeverything is bad with his head‚Äù, how much he controls his behavior, his life, and ‚Äúwho dances whom‚Äù.
What is this magical way? I tell you. This is a system of "plans for tomorrow."
In its most elementary form, it looks like this: during the day, you plan the next day one small-small business that you would have long had to do, but you can‚Äôt do another month or year.
This business should not be obligatory, that is, you can do it or not, it should be small (you don‚Äôt need to spend more than half an hour on it), simple, absolutely doable, and its implementation should depend only on you.
You can‚Äôt plan to get up in the morning and go to the toilet ‚Äî you will do so. You can‚Äôt plan to learn the conjugation of a hundred French verbs of the third group - this is impossible in a day. You can‚Äôt plan to meet your friend or dry clean your laundry ‚Äî a friend may not come, and dry cleaning may be closed. The plan should be useful, optional, simple, short-lived and feasible.
Then, during the next day, you must complete it and plan another one the next day. And so every day. For non-fulfillment of the plan for any most justifiable reasons, as well as for forgetting to plan it, as well as for forgetting what you planned, you assign yourself a fine of one percent of the total monthly income (including all sources of income). Total for the month in the worst case, you can lose thirty percent of monthly income. Not deadly, but biting.
This system has always been described as a tool to combat procrastination (putting things off for later), as a tool for ‚Äúcompleting gestalt‚Äù (a series of behavioral acts), and as a tool for phasing out large and complex tasks that allows you to ‚Äúeat an elephant in parts.‚Äù I agree with all this, but I do not agree that this is the main thing.
I believe that the main advantage of the ‚Äúplans for tomorrow‚Äù system is that it allows, through concrete actions, to see, define and realize the degree of uncontrollability of one‚Äôs psyche, the degree of uncontrollability of one‚Äôs behavior, to see and realize it as something other than ‚Äúyou‚Äù, intervenes in your decisions and controls your behavior.
The introduction of this system into life is like throwing a stick into a water stream. If you sit on the banks of a large and slow river, it is not always clear: in which direction it flows.
To understand, you need to throw the stick into the water and determine the direction of the flow by its movement. So it is here.
‚ÄúPlans for tomorrow‚Äù is an ‚Äúatomic‚Äù system. Less is nothing.
Watch your hands. Do you plan the next day what you need? Yes. This is not necessary for a neighbor, not for a husband, not for a wife, not for a boss, you need it. Do you need this for a long time? Yes. Can you do it tomorrow? Yes. Is it easy? Yes. Is it up to you? Yes. If you do not, then ‚Äúget on the head‚Äù - will you have to pay a fine? Yes.
And if you agree with all this and are 100% sure that you can cope with the implementation of ‚Äúplans for tomorrow‚Äù, then try. Less than five percent of people in my experience do this. In 95% of cases, people without problems agree to the introduction of a system of ‚Äúplans‚Äù in their life, but then they quickly discover that for some completely incomprehensible reasons they forgot to plan something, forgot to do it and, of course, forgot to pay a fine for forgetting and not fulfilling.
And here is the question: if ‚Äúyou‚Äù made the decision yesterday that ‚Äúplans‚Äù are an excellent solution to your problem of putting off business until later, then the question is, who didn‚Äôt fulfill this decision tomorrow, devalued and canceled it?
It was your unconscious that did not argue at the moment when you agreed to fulfill them and when you were sure that you could fulfill them. It didn‚Äôt argue when you planned something in the evening. It treated you like an unreasonable child who was about to fly into space tomorrow. Parents will not argue with the child and dissuade him. They just say ‚ÄúSleep, little‚Äù in the evening, and in the morning they say: ‚ÄúGet up, let's go to kindergarten. The flight is canceled for technical reasons. ‚Äù
The system of "plans" allows you to determine "who whom": you are your subconscious or it is you.
And there is practically no room for maneuver and dual interpretation. You have planned something, you want and can do it, but not you (!) Tomorrow, cancel it, forget it and somehow do not magically fulfill it.
And first a sad conclusion. Gentlemen, if you cannot organize yourself to perform one small, necessary, absolutely feasible business, then hope that you can organize yourself to carry out some large, complex and difficult tasks, you have no reason.
This does not mean at all that in your life pleasant moments and even achievements will not happen, but these will not be your achievements in the full sense of the word. A person who is floating along a river can be accidentally beaten to some nice and pretty place, and he can even ‚Äúachieve something,‚Äù but he should not console himself with the illusion that he controls his life and makes decisions himself. Such a person feels in his life not as a master, but as a grafter, who sits sadly in the kitchen and wonders: ‚ÄúCan you have dinner?‚Äù And not the fact that they will not feed her. Feed if the mood is good. But not she decides.
Ask yourself when you make a decision in the morning not to eat after seven in the evening, who tells you that very evening after seven: ‚ÄúAn interesting point of view, and now let's go eat, we have a delicious cake in the refrigerator, we are very tired today, nobody likes us, and you can‚Äôt live without a cake on such a difficult evening? ‚Äù Do you have an answer?
And now a pleasant conclusion, or rather life observation: those people who, through work, stress, constant fines and tears, have introduced into their lives a pseudo-simple system of ‚Äúplans for tomorrow‚Äù, for several years achieved not only what they dreamed about, but even of what they could not even dream of.



Yuri Vagin - candidate of medical sciences, a psychotherapist with 30 years of experience, author of articles, books and is popularisator of psychology. Over the years of practice, the doctor helped dozens of people figure out the causes of their problems and showed how to organize your life to make it as happy as possible.
In the book ‚ÄúDoctor, I have stress. Psychoses and fears of a big city ‚ÄùVagin tells where the stresses and overwork come from and what they lead to, how to deal with them and where to get strength for productivity.
